IdentificationModule.BriefTitle: CD49 in Optimization The Cologenicity of Mesenchymal Stem Cell Culture Passage
IdentificationModule.OfficialTitle: CD49 in Optimization The Cologenicity of Mesenchymal Stem Cell Culture Passage

ResponsibleParty.ResponsiblePartyInvestigatorTitle: resident doctor at clinical pathology in Sohag oncology center

DescriptionModule.BriefSummary: Human mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) due to their regenerative and immunomodulatory properties are widely used for the treatment of bone and cartilage damage, cardiovascular, gastrointestinal, autoimmune, neurodegenerative diseases and cancer .It is shown that the use of MSCs in therapy is safe and can be effective .In 2006, the International Society for Cellular Therapy (ISCT) proposed the minimal criteria to define human MSCs. First, MSCs must be plastic-adherent when maintained in the standard culture conditions. Second MSCs must express CD105, CD73 and CD90, and lack expression of CD45, CD34, CD14 or CD11b, CD79a or CD19 and HLA-DR surface molecules.

Intervention.InterventionDescription: take sample of Wharton jelly and culturing it to know the best time for mesenchymal stem cell growth

PrimaryOutcome.PrimaryOutcomeMeasure: evaluation the best passage of MSC culture by CD49 surface marker
PrimaryOutcome.PrimaryOutcomeDescription: evaluation the best passage of MSC culture by CD49 surface marker

EligibilityModule.EligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

normal babies delivered by normal labor

Exclusion Criteria:

diseased or congenital anomalies
EligibilityModule.StudyPopulation: taking umbilical cord of normally labored babies

Reference.ReferenceCitation: Lv FJ, Tuan RS, Cheung KM, Leung VY. Concise review: the surface markers and identity of human mesenchymal stem cells. Stem Cells. 2014 Jun;32(6):1408-19. doi: 10.1002/stem.1681. Review.

Madrigal M, Rao KS, Riordan NH. A review of therapeutic effects of mesenchymal stem cell secretions and induction of secretory modification by different culture methods. J Transl Med. 2014 Oct 11;12:260. doi: 10.1186/s12967-014-0260-8. Review.
